member.summary: An implementation of that does nothing (null object design pattern). Can be specialized.

member.name: T:CK.Core.IActivityLogger
member.summary: Simple activity logger for end user communication. This is not the same as a classical logging framework: this is dedicated to capture activities in order to display them to an end user.

member.name: M:CK.Core.IActivityLogger.UnfilteredLog(CK.Core.CKTrait,CK.Core.LogLevel,System.String,System.DateTime,System.Exception)
member.summary: Logs a text regardless of level. Each call to log is considered as a unit of text: depending on the rendering engine, a line or a paragraph separator (or any appropriate separator) should be appended between each text if the is the same as the previous one. See remarks.
member.param: Tags (from ) to associate to the log, unioned with current .
Text to log. Ignored if null or empty.
Timestamp of the log entry (must be UTC).
Optional exception associated to the log. When not null, a Group is automatically created.
member.returns: This logger to enable fluent syntax.
member.remarks: A null or empty is not logged. If needed, the special text ("PARK-LEVEL") breaks the current and resets it: the next log, even with the same LogLevel, will be treated as if a different LogLevel is used.

member.name: M:CK.Core.IActivityLogger.OpenGroup(CK.Core.CKTrait,CK.Core.LogLevel,System.Func{System.String},System.String,System.DateTime,System.Exception)
member.summary: Opens a log level. must be called in order to close the group, or the returned object must be disposed.
member.param: Tags (from ) to associate to the log, unioned with current .
Log level. Since we are opening a group, the current is ignored.
Optional function that will be called on group closing.
Text to log (the title of the group). Null text is valid and considered as or assigned to the if it exists.
Timestamp of the log entry (must be UTC).
Optional exception associated to the group.
member.returns: A disposable object that can be used to close the group.
member.remarks: A group opening is not filtered since any subordinated logs may occur with a much higher level. It is left to the implementation to handle (or not) filtering when is called.

member.name: M:CK.Core.IActivityLogger.CloseGroup(System.DateTime,System.Object)
member.summary: Closes the current Group. Optional parameter is polymorphic. It can be a string, a , a or an of ActivityLogGroupConclusion, or any object with an overriden method. See remarks (especially for List<ActivityLogGroupConclusion>).
member.param: Optional string, ActivityLogGroupConclusion object, enumerable of ActivityLogGroupConclusion or object to conclude the group. See remarks.
Timestamp of the closing of the group.
member.remarks: An untyped object is used here to easily and efficiently accomodate both string and already existing ActivityLogGroupConclusion. When a List<ActivityLogGroupConclusion> is used, it will be direclty used to collect conclusion objects (new conclusions will be added to it). This is an optimization.

member.name: P:CK.Core.IActivityLogger.AutoTags
member.summary: Gets or sets the tags of this logger: any subsequent logs will be tagged by these tags. The must be registered in . Modifications to this property are scoped to the current Group since when a Group is closed, this property (and ) is automatically restored to its original value (captured when the Group was opened).

member.name: T:CK.Core.ActivityLoggerBridgeTarget
member.summary: This class (a ), used with , enables to be used across Application Domains. It can also be used to relay logs inside the same application domain. This ActivityLoggerBridgeTarget must be created in the original and bound to the final activity logger (the target). The ActivityLoggerBridge (that is a ) can be created in remote AppDomain (and registered in the of a logger in the remote AppDomain) bound to the ActivityLoggerBridgeTarget (one can use to transfer the ActivityLoggerBridgeTarget to the other AppDomain for instance).

member.param: Tags (from ) to associate to the log, combined with current .
Text to log. Ignored if null or empty.
Timestamp of the log entry (must be Utc).
Optional exception associated to the log. When not null, a Group is automatically created.
member.returns: This logger to enable fluent syntax.
member.remarks: A null or empty is not logged. If needed, the special text ("PARK-LEVEL") breaks the current and resets it: the next log, even with the same LogLevel, will be treated as if a different LogLevel is used.

member.summary: Opens a configured with the given parameters.
member.param: Tags (from ) to associate to the log, combined with current .
The log level of the group.
Optional function that will be called on group closing to obtain a conclusion if no explicit conclusion is provided through .
Text to log (the title of the group). Null text is valid and considered as or assigned to the if it exists.
Timestamp of the log entry (must be UTC).
Optional exception associated to the group.
member.returns: The that can be disposed to close it.

member.name: M:CK.Core.ActivityLogger.CloseGroup(System.DateTime,System.Object)
member.summary: Closes the current . Optional parameter is polymorphic. It can be a string, a , a or an of ActivityLogGroupConclusion, or any object with an overriden method. See remarks (especially for List<ActivityLogGroupConclusion>).
member.param: Optional string, enumerable of ) or object to conclude the group. See remarks.
member.remarks: An untyped object is used here to easily and efficiently accomodate both string and already existing ActivityLogGroupConclusion. When a List<ActivityLogGroupConclusion> is used, it will be direclty used to collect conclusion objects (new conclusions will be added to it). This is an optimization.

member.name: P:CK.Core.ActivityLogger.AutoTags
member.summary: Gets or sets the tags of this logger: any subsequent logs will be tagged by these tags. The must be registered in . Modifications to this property are scoped to the current Group since when a Group is closed, this property (like ) is automatically restored to its original value (captured when the Group was opened).

member.name: M:CK.Core.ActivityLoggerExtension.OpenGroup(CK.Core.IActivityLogger,CK.Core.LogLevel,System.Func{System.String},System.String,System.Object[])
member.summary: Opens a log level. CloseGroup must be called in order to close the group, or the returned object must be disposed.

member.name: T:CK.Core.CriticalErrorCollector
member.summary:
This collector keeps s (and no more). It raises event on each . It is totally thread-safe and guaranties (as long as its Capacity is big enough) that no error can be lost (even errors raised while dispatching the event are themselves collected) and that errors are dispatched in sequence.
This class is typically used as a static property or field by any object that must handle unexpected errors. (It can also be used per-instance if it makes sense.)

member.name: M:CK.Core.CriticalErrorCollector.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new with a default set to 64.

member.name: M:CK.Core.CriticalErrorCollector.Add(System.Exception,System.String)
member.summary: Adds a critical, unexpected error.
member.param: Comment associated to the error (such as the name of the culprit). Can be null.
The unexpected exception. Must not be null.

member.name: M:CK.Core.CriticalErrorCollector.Clear
member.summary: Clears the list. Only errors that have been already raised by are removed from the internal buffer: it can be safely called at any time.
member.returns: The number of errors waiting to be raised.

member.name: M:CK.Core.CriticalErrorCollector.WaitOnErrorFromBackgroundThreadsPending
member.summary: Blocks the caller thread until no more event is waiting to be raised by or is being processed. This is the right function to use instead of pooling .

member.name: M:CK.Core.CriticalErrorCollector.ToArray
member.summary: Obtains a copy of the last (up to) errors from oldest to newest. The newest may have not been raised by yet.
member.returns: An independent array.

member.name: E:CK.Core.CriticalErrorCollector.OnErrorFromBackgroundThreads
member.summary:
Fires when an error has been ed (there cannot be more than one thread that raises this event at the same time). Raising this event is itself protected: if an exception is raised by one of the registered EventHandler, the culprit is removed from the OnErrorFromBackgroundThreads list of delegates, the exception is appended in the collector, and a new event will be raised (to the remaining handlers).
Caution: the event always fire on a background thread (adding an error is not a blocking operation).

member.name: P:CK.Core.CriticalErrorCollector.Capacity
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximal number of errors kept by this collector. Defaults to 64 (which should be enough). It can be safely changed at any time.

member.name: P:CK.Core.CriticalErrorCollector.OnErrorFromBackgroundThreadsPending
member.summary: Gets whether any event is waiting to be raised by or is being processed. When this is false, it is guaranteed that any existing errors have been handled: if no more can be done it means that this collector has finished its job. Instead of pooling this property - with an horrible Thread.Sleep( 1 ), you should use to more efficiently and securely wait for the end of this collector's job.

member.name: P:CK.Core.CriticalErrorCollector.NextSequenceNumber
member.summary: Gets the next . Getting this property makes sense only if this collector is not being solicited.

member.name: P:CK.Core.CriticalErrorCollector.DispatchQueuedWorkItemCount
member.summary: Gets the number of internally created queued work items since this collector exists.

member.name: P:CK.Core.CriticalErrorCollector.OptimizedDispatchQueuedWorkItemCount
member.summary: Gets the number of work items that have been saved since another one was ready to dispatch the events. This is a measure of an internal optimization that makes sense only under heavy loads (unit tests).

member.name: T:CK.Core.ICKReadOnlyCollection`1
member.summary: Represents a generic read only collections of objects with a contravariant method. This enables collection implementing this interface to support better lookup complexity than O(n) if possible.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements in the collection.

member.name: M:CK.Core.ICKReadOnlyCollection`1.Contains(System.Object)
member.summary: Determines whether collection contains a specific value.
member.param: The object to find in the collecion.
member.returns: True if item is found in the collection; otherwise, false.

member.name: T:CK.Core.ICKReadOnlyList`1
member.summary: Represents a read only collection of objects that can be individually accessed by index.
member.typeparam: The type of elements in the list.

member.name: M:CK.Core.ICKReadOnlyList`1.IndexOf(System.Object)
member.summary: Determines the index of a specific item in the list.
member.param: The object to locate in the list.
member.returns: A positive index of the item in this list, if found, a negative index otherwise. If this list is sorted, this must work exactly like : if the item is not found and could be added, the result is a negative number which is the bitwise complement of the index at which the new item should be inserted. To handle the case where the item can NOT be inserted and to be consistent with the positive/negative index semantics, the must be returned. See remarks.

remarks.para: The fact that is used to indicate an "impossible index" enables this covariant list to gracefully handle the case where the item's type is more general that the actual type list.

Similarly, if the implementation is associated to any kind of filters, returning instead of any other negative value indicates to the caller that the item does not appear in the list, but more than that, that it CAN NOT appear.

Note that an implementation can perfectly ignore these guidelines and returns -1 (typically) for any unexisting items: it is not an obligation to challenge any possible filters or constraints inside this IndexOf method.
On the other hand, if this method returns then it MUST mean that the item can NOT appear in this list.

member.summary: A trait is an immutable object (thread-safe), associated to a unique string inside a , that can be atomic ("Alt", "Home", "Ctrl") or combined ("Alt|Ctrl", "Alt|Ctrl|Home"). member.summary: Obtains a where the atomic traits of are removed (resp. added) depending on whether they exist (resp. do not exist) in this trait. This is like an Exclusive Or (XOR).

member.name: M:CK.Core.CKTrait.Process(CK.Core.CKTrait,CK.Core.CKTrait,System.Predicate{CK.Core.CKTrait},System.Predicate{CK.Core.CKTrait},System.Predicate{CK.Core.CKTrait})
member.summary: Common process function where 3 predicates drive the result: each atomic trait is submitted to one of the 3 predicates depending on whether it is only in the left, only in the right or appears in both traits. When returning false, a predicate stops the process.
member.remarks:
When this predicate is 'adding the trait to a list', we can draw the following table where '1' means the predicate exists and '0' means no predicate (or the 'always true' one):
0, 0, 0 = -- 'Empty' Intersect 0, 0, 1 = Intersect (keep commons) => /Toggle 0, 1, 0 = -- 'Cleanup' (keep theirs only) => /Remove 0, 1, 1 = -- 'Other' (keep theirs and commons, reject mine) => /This Except 1, 0, 0 = Remove (keep mine only) => /Cleanup 1, 0, 1 = -- 'This' (keep mine and commons and reject theirs) => /Other Toggle 1, 1, 0 = Toggle (keep mine, theirs, but reject commons) => /Intersect Union 1, 1, 1 = Add
This shows that our 4 methods Intersect, Remove, Toggle and Add cover the interesting cases - others are either symetric or useless.

member.name: T:CK.Core.ReadOnlyListOnIList`2
member.summary: Adapts a object to the interface where TInner is a T.
member.typeparam: Type of the exposed element.
Type of the list element.
member.remarks:
There is no way to define a beast like ReadOnlyListOnIList<T, TInner> where TInner : T that would extend because of the GetEnumerator support.
The adapter object would have to implement both GetEnumerator() methods (for TInner and T), and even if the constraint states that TInner is T and the IEnumerator is covariant, this is rejected with the following error: cannot implement both 'IEnumerable<T>' and 'System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable<TInner>' because they may unify for some type parameter substitutions.

member.name: T:CK.Core.OSVersionInfo.SimpleOSLevel
member.summary: Captures simple Windows operating system versions. The idea is to rely on release time to ease simple version check (ie. OSLevel >= SimpleOSLevel.WindowsVista). The bit applies to Windows NT 4.0 and above: it breaks the lines of old Windows desktop editions (Windows 98, ME) and enables for instance Windows2000 to be considered as greater than WindowsME.
member.remarks: Of course, feature detection is always a best choice, but for simple tests this is enough and keeps things simple.

member.name: T:CK.Core.ChangeStatus
member.summary: Defines a common change status: it captures the main kind of changes that an object or container can support. This status does not pretend to describe all and every possible changes, it is a trade-off between explicit, simple and well defined terms and the horrifying complexity reality.

member.name: F:CK.Core.ChangeStatus.None
member.summary: No operation occured.

member.name: F:CK.Core.ChangeStatus.Update
member.summary: Denotes the update of an object.

member.name: F:CK.Core.ChangeStatus.Add
member.summary: Denotes a new object (typically the appearing of an item in a collection). It should have been named 'Appear' but 'Add' is a much more common term to refer to object apparition in classical collection scenario.

member.name: F:CK.Core.ChangeStatus.Delete
member.summary: Denotes the suppression of an object (typically the removing of an item from a collection).

member.name: F:CK.Core.ChangeStatus.ContainerClear
member.summary: Denotes the suppression of the content of a container object (typically when destroying a collection): no more content exist.

member.name: F:CK.Core.ChangeStatus.ContainerUpdate
member.summary: Denotes a global change in the content of container object (typically the replacement of items in a collection with items from another one).

member.name: F:CK.Core.ChangeStatus.ContainerDestroy
member.summary: Denotes a global change in the content of container object (typically when clearing a collection): no more values exist.
